title: Best way to secure a newly built apartment?
self_text: Hi everyone. I need a bit of advice on the current situation I'm in. I inspected an apartment in a building that has still been finalized (workers painting, installing TVs, etc.) a few weeks ago, and the showing agent advised that the apartments would be ready to move in in 3-4 weeks. I’ve applied and followed up with the real estate agency a couple of times. The agency is saying that they cannot sign the lease with me because they don’t know when exactly the apartment will be finalized and ready to rent, but that this should happen sometime in November (up to Nov 20th). I was told on the phone that my application is successful but the application is still in ‘processing’ status and I don’t have any written confirmation that I’m a successful applicant for this unit. I’m currently living in a temporary place (until the end of Nov) and I’ll start following up again / going to inspections from Nov 14th or so, but I was just wondering if there is a standard kind of confirmation people usually get in a situation like mine? Should I insist that they at least send an email confirming that I am a successful applicant for this apartment (formally, that’s non-binding, though)? Thanks in advance!

title: Why is the visa and mastercard exchange rate poor?
self_text: I have a Santander Zero card which has 0% fees on foreign currency transactions. Pre-covid, I used to travel a lot and use it extensively. I'm obviously remembering a while back now, but I'm pretty sure the exchange rate it would achieve was pretty close to what google would tell you or if you would go and look at a live spot rate exchange rate price. Not 100% but to a point of being fairly negligible. I used to expense a lot for work too so I was regularly looking at this and from memory it was very close.  However, I just made a large online purchase that was in USD last night and the pound amount that has been charged is a lot higher than I was expecting. Doing the math, it worked out at around 1.129 as the exchange rate, whereas the real exchange rate was 1.151 when I made the transaction. That’s nearly a 2% fee, which is a pretty significant spread.  I initially thought my card had stopped being 0% fee as they don't offer it anymore but I still have it but have since found https://www.mastercard.co.uk/en-gb/personal/get-support/convert-currency.html, which seems to give a similar estimate for the transaction cost as I was charged, so it seems to be mastercard. The Visa one is similar.  Has this always been the case or have the exchange rates got worse? I know there were certain EU regulations around some card charges and the Visa calculator mentioned the ECB rate so I’m wondering if this is a post-Brexit thing as I haven't really made any foreign transactions since we officially left. Or otherwise, has the spread always been this high and I just have a poor memory? Other than directly sending cash via online brokers or foreign currency platforms, are there any better options for purchases than a standard 0% foreign fee mastercard or visa card?

title: How to improve my PC’s thermal performance
self_text: I’ve been running a PC for a couple of years now, and recently I’ve noticed it’s been throttling frequently, especially during demanding tasks like video editing. I’ve monitored the temperatures and it’s consistently hitting around 85°C on the CPU. I’ve got a decent cooler (Corsair iCUE H150i Elite Capellix), but I suspect it's not performing optimally. I’ve tried adjusting fan curves in the BIOS and through Corsair’s iCUE software, but haven’t seen a dramatic improvement. What are some effective strategies for improving thermal performance beyond just tweaking fan speeds? Any recommendations for monitoring tools or diagnostics would also be helpful.
